author: .vbuterin
content:
The reason I stress the ZK prover angle so much is:

We have a goal to maximize L1 gas limit, subject to complying with decentralization goals, which realistically we will formalize into something that includes a statement like "any operation that ethereum needs to get done, you can do on hardware that costs $X and runs on Y watts and needs Z bandwidth"

And it is looking right now like ZK proving is the biggest bottleneck there. It has a 100-1000x overhead over regular execution (today, I think over 1000x, but that will decrease; in the limit of technology I could imagine ZK proving getting to under 10x overhead, but that will take a while)

author: daniellehrner
content:
You can remove reverted txs from block building from Reth today, nobody is stopping you. Deal with the potential DOS issue and its done. No need for centralised block building.

There are alternatives to sandwiching by block builders: Let smart contracts define their own transaction order rules. If block builders don't follow them the block is invalid. Sandwiching can still happen, but now instead of block builders sandwiching anonymous people, the apps will sandwich their own users and drive them to competitors if they abuse that. No need for centralised block building.

Today we have more than 10.000 nodes that can build blocks on Ethereum, once we centralise we'll have less than 10 (looking at Bitcoin). We risk Ethereum's 100% uptime if we reduce the number of block builder by orders of magnitudes. How is that a user-centric approach?

author: daniellehrner
content:
Thank you for that. I raised some questions there, but there is another question that bothers me. What is the current holistic approach to ensure that we don't lose home stakers in the future?

We normally only discuss one proposal at a time, but putting several proposals together let's me think that we might have issues to retain home stakers in the future. For example the following issues:

1) Raising hardware requirements for stakers: Dankrad mentioned a 10k USD target for home stakers, maybe that is cheaper depending on which node it is
2) Changes to the issuance curve: Most proposals want to keep staked ETH low and the issuance go to zero sooner or later.
3) Home stakers that still can build blocks can get tips from the tx that they include. But at the same time the public mem pool is bleeding out and it seems nothing about that will change in the future

Why would any rational person stake from home at this point, if they don't get paid (issuance = 0, tips for txs ~0), have high initial costs and risk to lose their stake if they make a mistake and get slashed, or their clients happens to be a > 2/3 majority client and it has a bug?

author: barnabemonnot
content:
All of these questions to me are downstream of what we want/need home *operators* for, actually whether they stake or not is one dimension of our design space
- do we want them to directly participate in finality, or are we happy enough with indirect participation? https://ethresear.ch/t/paths-to-ssf-revisited/22052
- do we want them to serve RPC requests/blob samples, and if so how many and how?
- do we want them to participate in block building directly, or indirectly with FOCIL is enough? maybe we want both but in different regimes (e.g., one is a fallback, the other is the average case)
- probably many more questions related to different types of services like archives/history etc.

One message we tried to convey in the first protocol research call (https://www.youtube.com/live/m5HFO4DYckQ?si=4fD0Z7PkJM-4pBpX) is that we should not be thinking about these questions from the viewpoint of what the home staking experience looks like today, but reverse-engineering roles and requirements from the services we want to see performed by different classes of providers, given new mechanisms such as FOCIL, zkEVMs, DAS etc. the world will look very different and we should not index on the current shapes

author: peter.davies
content:
My perspective on what happened:

Until recently, there was a weak and relatively fragile consensus in favour of going ahead with "Complete EOF" (Option A). Then there were complaints that part of EOF (banning gas and extcode introspection) would break so much current Solidity code that it would be unusable and everyone would be forced to continue using the legacy EVM. This came up during ACDE on 24th April, because we are so close to freezing Osaka and deploying the first devnets there wasn't time to delay the decision to ACDE on 8th May and so it was scheduled to be made at the testing call on the 28th. This is a fairly standard practice for making urgent decisions.

At the testing call, Ipsilon presented an options paper with 4 options, although only two had a serious chance of achieving consensus:

A: Complete EOF, same as before accept possible day 1 unusability.
D: Introspecting EOF, remove the "bans" causing the issue and keep everything else.

EOF then lost consensus for two reasons. Firstly, several people on or close to the fence got uncertain and became actively opposed. Secondly, the coalition backing EOF got split between people who would only accept A (because, if we don't ban introspection now, we have to introduce EOFv2 to ban it later) and people who would only accept D (because A would cause major dev tooling breakage). This is a general property of group decision making, a group of people who individually hold logically consistent views can be collectively irrational. There can be a majority support for EOF in general and majority opposition to every individual form of EOF.

Faced with no immediate consensus on the way forward, the only choice was to delay Fusaka while the issues got worked out or drop EOF from Fusaka. Given the overwhelming consensus about the importance of not delaying PeerDAS, EOF had to be dropped. No decision was made about the longer term future of EOF.

author: peter.davies
content: I think that I should emphasise that approximately 0 people are happy about this decision. The general impasse about EOF, that we explicitly decided to break by including EOF in Osaka has been reinstated. If EOF dies, then a huge amount of dev time has been wasted. If EOF lives, it will have to be included in a future fork (possibly an EL only fork) which will delay other important EL features.
